info.game_comments:
Russ Schumacher game 2.
(Sofia: Hello, tiny ant people!  Stay tuned for clues aboard the Goodyear Blimp, next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew in the Goodyear Blimp)  I'm in California aboard the Spirit of America; her sister blimp, the Spirit of Goodyear, is based near this "rubber capital"

(3, 1).clue: Chapter 9 of this novel is entitled "Meg Goes to Vanity Fair"

(4, 1).clue: Crowds of 30,000 are the rule for commencement at this Austin school

(5, 1).clue: On May 1, 1873 the first postcards at this postage rate were issued

(6, 1).clue: 1995 film in which actor Beau's brother has a love affair in Iowa with Meryl Streep

(1, 2).clue: Air-filled ballonets control how much this gas is allowed to expand in the envelope

(2, 2).clue: 1966:This TV band with "Last Train To Clarksville"

(3, 2).clue: The Charles Ingalls family moves to the Great Plains area in this 1935 novel

(4, 2).clue: A statue of this reptile movie terror stands about 8 feet tall on top of Austin's Mangia Pizza on Guadalupe Street

(5, 2).clue: In 1825 the Marquis de Lafayette laid the cornerstone for a monument to this battle

(6, 2).clue: Perhaps Salome danced to "Crocodile Rock" when demanding the head of this singer & voice in the wilderness

(1, 3).clue: (Sofia standing in front of the Goodyear Blimp)  The blimp captain controls the elevators, the horizontal fins, & these steering devices, the vertical fins

(3, 3).clue: This pal of Robin Hood stood out in a crowd: he was at least 7 feet tall

(4, 3).clue: A statue commemorating these lawmen stands in front of the state capitol in Austin

(5, 3).clue: Name of the ship that James Lawrence urged his men, "Don't give up", it was also paired in a railroad with Ohio

(6, 3).clue: Mr. Romano's sitcom featuring the hard-boiled writer of "The Big Sleep"

(1, 4).clue: A winter visitor to Florida, or a Goodyear airship that stayed aloft for 11 days, going from Massachusetts to Florida via Africa

(2, 4).clue: 1999:Christina Aguilera with this song that rubbed listeners the right way

(3, 4).clue: The mousy hero of this E.B. White book leaves home to search for the bird who's his dearest friend

(4, 4).clue: Built in 1856 & now home to Rick Perry, it's located at 1010 Colorado Street in Austin

(5, 4).clue: In 1863 he patented his popular folding upper berth

(6, 4).clue: Star of TV's "The Dead Zone" who checks students' passes if they're en route to the loo during classtime

(1, 5).clue: (Sofia standing in front of the Goodyear Blimp)  The Goodyear Blimp's skin isn't made with natural rubber, but this synthetic rubber made from chloroprene

(2, 5).clue: 1983:This heavy metal group with "Cum on Feel the Noize"

(3, 5).clue: Regina Giddens is the vixenish lead character of this 1939 Lillian Hellman play

(4, 5).clue: A museum in Austin is dedicated to this "Gift of the Magi" author who lived in the city for many years

(5, 5).clue: 1889 event that caused the damage seen here

(6, 5).clue: Hong Kong action star of "The Replacement Killers" who's the English name for the day before Lent

(1, 1).clue: One of the smallest of these "white" diminutive stars is Van Maanen's Star at 7,800 miles in diameter

(2, 1).clue: This international newsmaker was on the cover of the May 29 issue in all her crowning glory

(3, 1).clue: Just across the Mexican border, Tijuana is the cuate, or twin, of this U.S. city

(4, 1).clue: Hearsay & leading the witness are grounds for this during testimony

(5, 1).clue: When Lorenz Hart declined to work on the show that became "Oklahoma!", Richard Rodgers partnered with him

(6, 1).clue: A small earthquake or tremor that occurs following a major one

(1, 2).clue: Crickets "hear" via highly sensitive membranes on these body parts

(2, 2).clue: Was he on the cover of the July 24 issue?  "You Bet Your Life" he was

(3, 2).clue: Go up the north face of Mount Everest & down the south face & you'll cross from Tibet into this country

(4, 2).clue: Personal injury lawyers may work on this type of fee, a percentage of the money awarded

(5, 2).clue: "Rhapsody in Blue", a piece by this composer, was used as the title of a 1945 movie biography of him

(6, 2).clue: Tim Burton's spooky stop-motion animated feature from 1993

(1, 3).clue: In 1857 this French chemist's theory of fermentation was first presented in a paper "on Lactic Fermentation"

(2, 3).clue: Just the facts, Ma'am: he missed being on the first cover by 1 week & was back the end of the year on the Dec. 11 cover

(3, 3).clue: The problem with the Maginot Line was it covered France's border with Germany, but not with this country

(4, 3).clue: If you fill out lots of EOIR-40s, applications for suspension of deportation, this area of law is your specialty

(5, 3).clue: He wrote the words & music to "I Happen to Like New York" & "I Love Paris"

(1, 4).clue: This whale, whose name is from Russian for "white", is born grey or brown; it turns a milky white by age 5

(2, 4).clue: An investigative report in the November 6 issue looked into why this man "Fired Julius La Rosa"

(3, 4).clue: Argentina's border with this country is 3,200 miles long, about the same as its coastline

(4, 4).clue: Some firms require lawyers to amass a minimum weekly number, like 40, of these, for which a client can be charged

(5, 4).clue: He collaborated with Yip Harburg on "Lydia, the Tattooed Lady" & "Over the Rainbow"

(6, 4).clue: 1840 Richard Henry Dana memoir that became one of the most popular tales of life at sea

(1, 5).clue: Seed plants are divided into 2 main groups: angiosperms & these, which include the conifers

(2, 5).clue: The cover story on this actor was subtitled "Man and Superman"

(3, 5).clue: A monument at Pervoururalsk in the Ural Mountains marks this geographic border

(5, 5).clue: This "Moon River" lyricist has been called "The Sentimental Gentleman from Georgia"

(6, 5).clue: It's the title of the 1894 "Prelude" heard here
(6, 5).correct response: "Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun"

(0, 0).clue: In the 2002 film "Frida", Geoffrey Rush portrayed this European firebrand during his final days
